case_name: Gurubachan Singh v. Commissioner of Police, Bombay

facts.text: Original Jurisdiction Petition No. 76 of 1952 filed.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURIDICTIN Petition No. 76 of 1952. Application under-Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for a writ in the nature of mandamus.

facts.text: Application under Article 32 of the Constitution for writ of mandamus.

anchor.surface_text: Application under-Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for a writ in the nature of mandamus. J. Umrigar for the petitioner. N. Joshi for the respondent.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on May 7, 1952 by MUKHERJEA J.

anchor.surface_text: 1952. May 7. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MUKHERJEA J.--This is an application under article 32 of the Constitution, presented by one Gurubachan Singh,

facts.text: Petitioner is Gurubachan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: This is an application under article 32 of the Constitution, presented by one Gurubachan Singh, praying for a writ, in the nature of mandamus restraining the respondents

facts.text: Petitioner is an Indian citizen residing with his father at Gogri Niwas, Vincent Road, Dadar.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner is an Indian citizen and is said to be residing with his father at a place called Gogri Niwas, Vincent Road, Dadar, his father having a business in elec- trical goods in the city of Bombay

facts.text: Father of petitioner has business in electrical goods in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: his father having a business in elec- trical goods in the city of Bombay On the 23rd July, 1951, the petitioner was served with an order purporting to have been made by the Commissioner of Police, Bombay,

facts.text: On 23rd July 1951, petitioner served with externment order by Commissioner of Police, Bombay under section 27(1) of City of Bombay Police Act 1902.

anchor.surface_text: On the 23rd July, 1951, the petitioner was served with an order purporting to have been made by the Commissioner of Police, Bombay, under section 27  1  of the City of Bombay Police Act  1902 . The petitioner is an Indian citizen and is said to be residing with his father

facts.text: Externment order directed petitioner to remove from Greater Bombay to Amritsar within two days by rail.

anchor.surface_text: directing him to remove himself from Greater Bombay and go to his native place at Amritsar in East Punjab. It was mentioned in the order that the petitioner was to companyply with its directions within two days from the date it was made, and that he was to proceed to Amritsar by rail.

facts.text: On July 25, 1951, petitioner applied to Commissioner for extension of time, granted till July 30, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: On July 25, 1951, the petitioner made an application to the Commissioner of Police and prayed for an extension of the time within which he was to remove himself from Greater Bombay, and on this application the Commissioner of Police gave him time till the 30th of July next.

facts.text: On 30th July 1951, petitioner wrote letter to Commissioner not desiring to go to Amritsar, requested to stay at Kalyan with railway ticket from Dadar.

anchor.surface_text: On 30th July, 1951, the petitioner himself wrote a letter to the Commissioner of Police stating that he did number desire to go to Amritsar and prayed that he might be allowed to stay at Kalyan which is outside Greater Bombay but within the Slate of Bombay and that he might be given a Railway ticket from Dadar to that place.

facts.text: Police took petitioner to Kalyan on evening of 30th July 1951 and left him there.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that acting on this letter the police took the petitioner to Kalyan on the evening of 30th July, 1951, and left him there. After that, the petitioner companymenced proceedings in the Bombay High Court

facts.text: Petitioner filed proceedings in Bombay High Court original side under Letters Patent, dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: After that, the petitioner companymenced proceedings in the Bombay High Court first in its original side under the Letters Patent and then in the Appellate Criminal Bench of the Court under articles 226 and 228 of the Constitution, companyplaining of the externment order

facts.text: Petitioner filed in Appellate Criminal Bench of Bombay High Court under Arts 226 and 228, dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: first in its original side under the Letters Patent and then in the Appellate Criminal Bench of the Court under articles 226 and 228 of the Constitution, companyplaining of the externment order mentioned above and praying for a writ of certiorari to have it quashed.

facts.text: Petitioner approached Supreme Court under Art 32 alleging infringement of Art 19(1)(d) and (e).

anchor.surface_text: Both these applications were dismissed and the petitioner has number companye up to this companyrt under article 32 of the Constitution on the allegation that his fundamental rights under clauses  d  and  e  of article 19 1  of the Constitution have been infringed by the extern- ment order.

facts.text: Externment order passed on 23-7-1951 not in strict conformity with s.27(1), not disputed by respondents.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the first point, it is number disputed on behalf of the respondents that the order of externment, as was passed by the Commissioner of Police on 23-7-1951, is number in strict companyformity with the provision of section 27 1  of the City of Bombay Police Act

facts.text: Order directed removal from Greater Bombay but specified Amritsar outside State.

anchor.surface_text: The order directed the petitioner to remove himself out of Greater Bombay but at the same time mentioned Amritsar as the place where he was to go Section 27 1  of the City of Bombay Police Act provides as follows--

facts.text: Kalyan is outside Greater Bombay but within State of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: stay at Kalyan which is outside Greater Bombay but within the Slate of Bombay and that he might be given a Railway ticket from Dadar to that place. It appears that acting on this letter the police took the petitioner to Kalyan

facts.text: Amritsar is in East Punjab, outside State of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: remove himself from Greater Bombay and go to his native place at Amritsar in East Punjab. It was mentioned in the order that the petitioner was to companyply with its directions within two days

facts.text: Court holds irregularity in order cured by petitioner's subsequent conduct and acceptance to go to Kalyan.

anchor.surface_text: We need number, however, labour this aspect of the matter any further, for we are of the opinion that whatever irregu- larity there might have been in the original order, the subsequent companyduct of the petitioner which had the sanction and approval of the Commissioner of Police removed the defect, if any.

facts.text: Petitioner's request to stay at Kalyan acceded to by Commissioner and police took him there.

anchor.surface_text: As has been stated already, on the 30th July, 1951, the petitioner himself by a letter written to the Commis- sioner of Police sought his permission to stay at Kalyan which is within the State of Bombay. His request was acced- ed to and the Police actually took him to Kalyan

facts.text: Maximum duration of externment order under s.27(1) is two years.

anchor.surface_text: The maximum dura- tion of the externment order made under section 27  1  of the Bombay Act is a period of two years and the Commissioner of Police can always permit the externee to enter the pro- hibited area even before the expiration of that period.

facts.text: Before passing order, Commissioner must inform person of allegations and give opportunity to explain, appear through advocate, file statement, examine witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the procedure to be followed in such cases, section 27  4  of the Act lays down that before an order of externment is passed against any person, the Commissioner of Police or any officer authorized by him shall inform such person, in writing, of the general nature of the material allegations against him and give him a reasonable opportunity of ex- plaining these allegations.

facts.text: Petitioner argued order void for non-conformity with s.27(1).

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Umrigar appearing in support of the petition has argued before us, in the first place that the order of externment is altogether void as it is number in companyformity with the provisions of section 27 1 of the City of Bombay Police Act.

facts.text: Petitioner argued s.27(1) conflicts with Art 19(1)(d) and (e), void under Art 13(1).

anchor.surface_text: His second companytention is that the provisions of section 27 1  of the City of Bombay Police Act being in companyflict with the fundamental rights enunciated in clauses  d  and  e  of article 19 1  of the Constitution are void under article 13 1  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Petitioner argued s.27(1) discriminatory under Art 14.

anchor.surface_text: The last companyten- tion urged, though somewhat faintly, is. that the provision of section 27 1  mentioned above is discriminatory in its character and offends against article 14 of the Constitu- tion.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURIDICTIN Petition No. 76 of 1952. Application under-Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for a writ in the nature of mandamus. J. Umrigar for the petitioner.

concepts.unlisted_description: Sought to restrain enforcement of externment order.

anchor.surface_text: under articles 226 and 228 of the Constitution, companyplaining of the externment order mentioned above and praying for a writ of certiorari to have it quashed.

issues.text: Whether the order of externment is altogether void as it is not in conformity with the provisions of section 27(1) of the City of Bombay Police Act?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Umrigar appearing in support of the petition has argued before us, in the first place that the order of externment is altogether void as it is number in companyformity with the provisions of section 27 1

issues.text: Whether section 27(1) of the City of Bombay Police Act imposes restrictions upon the fundamental right of a citizen under article 19(1)(d) of the Constitution and is void under article 13(1)?

anchor.surface_text: The second point urged by the learned counsel raises the question as to whether section 27 1 of the City of Bombay Police Act has imposed restrictions upon the funda- mental right of a citizen which is guaranteed under article 19 1 d of the Constitution and being in conflict with this fundamental right is void and inoperative under article 18 1 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the restrictions imposed by section 27(1) of the City of Bombay Police Act on the rights of free movement are reasonable within clause (5) of article 19?

anchor.surface_text: The question, therefore, is whether the restrictions that this law imposes upon the rights of free movement of a citizen, come within the purview of clause 5 of article 19 of the Constitution or in other words whether the restrictions are reasonable ?

issues.text: Whether the provisions of section 27(1) of the City of Bombay Police Act being in conflict with clauses (d) and (e) of article 19(1) are void under article 13(1)?

anchor.surface_text: His second contention is that the provisions of section 27 1  of the City of Bombay Police Act being in companyflict with the fundamental rights enunciated in clauses  d  and  e  of article 19 1  of the Constitution are void under article 13 1  of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the provision of section 27(1) of the City of Bombay Police Act is discriminatory and offends article 14 of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: The last contention urged, though somewhat faintly, is. that the provision of section 27 1  mentioned above is discriminatory in its character and offends against article 14 of the Constitu- tion.

arguments.court_reasoning: No cross-examination reasonable given legislative purpose to protect fearful witnesses from bad characters; would defeat object of law.

anchor.surface_text: There can be numberdoubt that the provision of section 27  1  of the Bombay Act was made in the interest of the general public and to protect them against dangerous

holdings.text: There are two kinds of externment orders contemplated by section 27(1): one directing removal from Greater Bombay specifying place within the State, route and time; the other from the State without specifying place.

anchor.surface_text: It seems clear from this provision that there are two kinds of externment orders contemplated by the subsection one, where externment is directed from the Greater Bombay and the other where the externee is to remove himself from the State of Bombay. In the first class of cases the order has got to specify the place where the externee is to remove himself to and it must also indicate the route by which he has to reach that place. On the other hand, when the externment is from the State of Bombay, the externee can remain anywhere he likes outside the State and no place of residence can or need be mentioned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual interpretation distinguishing requirements based on whether externment is from Greater Bombay or the entire State.

holdings.text: Whatever irregularity there might have been in the original externment order was removed by the subsequent conduct of the petitioner which had the sanction and approval of the Commissioner of Police.

anchor.surface_text: We need number, however, labour this aspect of the matter any further, for we are of the opinion that whatever irregu- larity there might have been in the original order, the subsequent companyduct of the petitioner which had the sanction and approval of the Commissioner of Police removed the defect, if any.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's letter requesting to stay at Kalyan within State was acceded to and police escorted him there, curing defect in original order specifying out-of-State place.

holdings.text: There is really no substance in the contention that the externment order is void for non-conformity with section 27(1).

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that in these circumstances there is really any substance in the first point raised by Mr. Umrigar.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Irregularity cured by subsequent approved conduct; alternatively, order construable as from State.

holdings.text: Section 27(1) has not imposed unreasonable restrictions on the fundamental right under article 19(1)(d) and is not void under article 13(1); the restrictions are reasonable under article 19(5).

anchor.surface_text: The maximum dura- tion of the externment order made under section 27  1  of the Bombay Act is a period of two years and the Commissioner of Police can always permit the externee to enter the pro- hibited area even before the expiration of that period. Having regard to the class of cases to which this sub-sec- tion applies and t. he menace which an externment order passed under it is intended to avert, it is difficult to say that this provision is unreasonable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Maximum two-year duration, revocable at any time; aimed at protecting public from bad characters; considers substantive and procedural aspects.

holdings.text: The procedure under section 27(4) is reasonable; absence of right to cross-examine witnesses does not render it unreasonable.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion this by itself would number make the procedure unreasonable having regard to the avowed intention of the legislature in making the enact- ment. The law is certainly an extraordinary one and has been made only to meet those exceptional cases where numberwitnesses for fear of violence to their person or property are willing to depose publicly against certain bad charac- ters whose presence in certain areas companystitutes a menace to the safety of the public residing therein.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Informs allegations in writing, opportunity to explain, appear by advocate, file statement, examine witnesses; cross-examination would defeat purpose of protecting fearful witnesses from bad characters.

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

outcome.relief_summary: Writ of mandamus denied; externment order held valid after rectification; section 27(1) held constitutional and reasonable restriction under Article 19(5)

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion this by itself would number make the procedure unreasonable having regard to the avowed intention of the legislature in making the enact- ment. The law is certainly an extraordinary one and has been made only to meet those exceptional cases where numberwitnesses for fear of violence to their person or property are willing to depose publicly against certain bad charac- ters whose presence in certain areas companystitutes a menace to the safety of the public residing therein.

We do number think that in these circumstances there is really any substance in the first point raised by Mr. Umrigar.
